literature.title: Kisaeng Sijo: Women's Voices in Chosŏn Poetry
literature.introduction: The kisaeng (기생) were professional female entertainers trained in poetry, music, and dance. Their sijo poems offer a rare non-elite female perspective on love and loss in Chosŏn society. Like the Chunhyang story mentioned in Ebrey, kisaeng sijo explore love across social boundaries.

poets.name: Hongnang
poets.bio: Kisaeng from Kyŏngsŏng. Met the poet Ch'oe Kyŏngch'ang when he traveled there on government business. When they parted as he returned to Seoul, she attached this sijo to a willow branch—following the Chinese custom of giving willow at farewells.

poems.title: Wild Willow Branch
poems.text:
I chose a wild willow branch and plucked it to send it to you.
I want you to plant it by the window where you sleep.
When new leaves open in the night rains, think it is I that have come to you.
poems.note: The poem transforms parting into continued presence through the living willow.

poets.name: Hwang Jini
poets.bio: The most famous kisaeng poet. Only six sijo survive, but her legendary beauty, wit, and defiance of convention made her an icon. Her poems use elaborate wordplay and double meanings.

poems.title: Long Winter Night
poems.text:
Oh that I might capture the essence of this deep midwinter night
And fold it softly into the waft of a spring-moon quilt,
Then fondly uncoil it the night my beloved returns.
poems.note: Written about the winter solstice (dongji). The impossible wish to store time for later use with a lover.

poems.title: I Cut in Two
poems.text:
I cut in two
A long November night, and
Place half under the coverlet,
Sweet-scented as a spring breeze.
And when he comes, I shall take it out,
Unroll it inch by inch, to stretch the night.
poems.note: Same theme—preserving night for the beloved's return.

poems.title: Blue Mountains Speak of My Desire
poems.text:
Blue mountains speak of my desire,
Green waters reflect my Lover's love:
The mountains unchanging,
The waters flowing by.
Sometimes it seems the waters cannot forget me,
They part in tears, regretting, running away.
poems.note: Mountains (unchanging) and water (flowing) represent the constancy of desire versus the transience of love.

literature.connectionToReadings: The reformers were yangban men proposing to redistribute yangban land. Kisaeng occupied the lowest social position—their daughters became kisaeng, their sons slaves. Yet they produced poetry admired by the very class that exploited them. Their voices offer a counterpoint to the elite male reform discourse.

discussionHooks.question: Pak Chega argued Korea should learn technology from 'barbarian' Qing China. How does this compare to modern debates about technology transfer from geopolitical rivals?
The Throne (2015) depicts the suffocating Confucian hierarchy. How do films shape our understanding of the society Sirhak thinkers critiqued?
South Korea's 1950 land reform finally redistributed land as Sirhak scholars proposed 300 years earlier. Why did it take a war and foreign occupation to implement these ideas?
Is the modern critique of Korean chaebol the same as Pak Chega's attack on yangban parasites, or fundamentally different?
How do kisaeng poems compare to the elite male reformers we read about? What voices are missing from the reform debates?
